channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: Sweeping changes in Russia's curriculum for schoolchildren will cast Vladimir Putin as a pivotal historical figure and mark an end of openness to the West. A senior Kremlin bureaucrat told teachers, "We need to know how to infect them with our ideology." https://t.co/LbSDwln0l3 https://t.co/M2H6jTeK2V
William Olson, a right-wing lawyer, sent a memo to Donald Trump in December 2020 on how to seek to overturn the election. Read it here. https://t.co/aV3O28KASP

Ray Epps was taped before Jan. 6 urging people to go to the Capitol. Then he became the face of a conspiracy theory by pro-Trump forces that the FBI was behind the riot. Since then, he's been forced to sell his home and his business — and go into hiding. https://t.co/IARuukjsna

The value of the U.S. dollar is the strongest it has been in a generation, devaluing currencies around the world and unsettling the outlook for the global economy as it upends everything from vacation costs to the profitability of multinational companies. https://t.co/Vtwn4u1NNR

In Opinion
Joe Manchin's "refusal to agree to climate investments will hurt the economy he claims to want to protect," writes @leahstokes. "The package would have built domestic manufacturing, supporting more than 750,000 climate jobs annually." https://t.co/ezs85FTuSN

William Olson, a little-known conservative lawyer, encouraged Donald Trump's attempts to overturn the 2020 election with ideas that Olson later conceded could be regarded as tantamount to declaring "martial law" and even invite comparisons with Watergate. https://t.co/5sonnuBeJ0

A party in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, invited "Shrek" fans to translate their online obsessions with the ogre into reality. The Shrek Rave kicked off with Smash Mouth's "All Star" ringing through the speakers. https://t.co/7QFvZe3F4u https://t.co/9HatSoV2Ou

Egypt has tens of thousands of political prisoners. Some face trials. Others are trapped in a pretrial detention system. The New York Times created the first public record of that circular legal process, revealing thousands trapped in pretrial detention. https://t.co/Mvkku9afoC https://t.co/Ft6epKeZOe

A toddler with Down syndrome was happily pushing a stroller through a park in Ukraine. Then, in a flash of fire, her life was snuffed out by a Russian missile. https://t.co/oBoq648zOk https://t.co/aAfu6EaWjs

Allyson Felix leaves behind an unmatchable track and field legacy, having won her 19th world championship medal Friday, extending her record for the most medals at the world championships. "I think I felt all the emotions," she said after her final race. https://t.co/BDl0nfgzy8 https://t.co/5dQDUa6b1V

Starting on Saturday, people who are experiencing mental distress will be able to dial just three numbers to reach the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline. https://t.co/SuQDksi5t0 https://t.co/oWhw9b6T7C

The Jan. 6 panel issued a subpoena to the Secret Service seeking text messages from Jan. 5 and 6, 2021, which were said to have been erased.
https://t.co/ox7CqC20wF

House Democrats passed two bills ensuring abortion access, including the right to travel across state lines for services and giving health care providers the right to provide them. Neither has the votes to pass the Senate. https://t.co/f3MAilSbwj https://t.co/hkS1LTpRIO

Lizz Winstead, the co-creator of “The Daily Show,” has been steadfastly focused on abortion in the comedy world for most of the last decade. She has marshaled her contacts in the standup world to help abortion rights supporters turn protest into action. https://t.co/WyuD5RcgmE

In Opinion
“In the attention economy, Ms. Griner’s predicament seems as if it’s being somewhat ignored,” Roxane Gay writes. “More public pressure for action is necessary. ‘We are B.G.’ should be a viral rallying cry.” https://t.co/nuVtMv3Jpx
Calling, texting or emailing a friend just to say “hello” might seem like an insignificant gesture, but it can have a powerful effect, new research suggests. https://t.co/VqsEoBP4ha

U.S. hospitals are once again filling up with Covid patients, driven largely by the BA.5 subvariant. But many are struggling to find enough nurses as a chronic shortage shows signs of getting worse. https://t.co/7QlCkBtiA6
Breaking News: A drug kingpin who was convicted of killing a Drug Enforcement Agent and was wanted by the FBI has been captured in Mexico, officials said. https://t.co/WAVLSJmMTY

As millions of people baked in heat waves supercharged by climate change this week, one U.S. politician, Senator Joe Manchin — an ardent champion of the fossil fuel industry — doused hopes of immediate climate action in Washington, writes Somini Sengupta. https://t.co/v5ic9DqPHc
A new study — the largest to date — shows how the Covid vaccine may affect menstruation. Experts say, based on the findings, there is no cause for alarm. https://t.co/V5MvxkHwYU

A woman had a speech therapy appointment Thursday for her 4-year-old daughter, Liza, who had Down syndrome. Liza was killed in a Russian strike soon afterward, Ukrainian officials confirmed. https://t.co/mkOljL0JlR
Palestinian demonstrators in Jerusalem on Friday expressed frustration with Washington’s support for Israel and the Biden administration’s policies toward Palestinians. https://t.co/DhliNMe5Zn

Beto O’Rourke set a new Texas fund-raising record for state office with a $27.6 million haul over four months in the governor’s race, his campaign announced on Friday, saying that it had outpaced Gov. Greg Abbott, the Republican incumbent. https://t.co/ntI6taKOsU

House Democrats passed two bills ensuring abortion access, including the right to travel across state lines for services and giving health care providers the right to provide them. Neither has the votes to pass the Senate. https://t.co/w2Wkw8vCQL

Two pro-Trump state senators in Georgia and the chair of the state Republican Party were sent letters by an Atlanta prosecutor informing them they could be indicted, according to a person familiar with the inquiry. https://t.co/MZmFGETfT8

At the end of a meeting between President Biden and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia, an NBC News reporter, Peter Alexander, shouted “Jamal Khashoggi, will you apologize to his family?” Prince Mohammed and Biden ignored the question. https://t.co/aJWzG21P9T https://t.co/PDyfPSwN1n
Breaking News: President Biden said he told the Saudi crown prince Mohammed bin Salman in their private meeting that he considers him to blame for Jamal Khashoggi’s murder. https://t.co/beXV9gnT3l

NASA released this image of Jupiter from the James Webb Space Telescope. The planet is 430 million miles away from Earth. By comparison, the light of a galaxy in the "deep field" image traveled close to 80 billion trillion miles to get to us. https://t.co/4puSOGFLJ1 https://t.co/VS0rsXk9WD

About 4,000 beagles were rescued from a breeding and research facility in Virginia that left them underfed, ill and injured. The dogs are scheduled to be released starting today — and the authorities have about two months to find them new homes. https://t.co/pZ8KVVLuI9

Half of Meryl Streep’s acting is "glasses business."
"At some point you know they're coming off, and it's going to be fabulous," Amanda Hess writes. https://t.co/mBxf4B51Rn
Breaking News: The biggest cryptominers in the U.S. have the capacity to use as much power as the city of Houston, an investigation by congressional Democrats found. https://t.co/P0Vmh0ldNC
Breaking News: Britain’s national weather service issued its first-ever red-alert warning for heat, with extreme temperatures expected on Monday and Tuesday. https://t.co/rAXgQ489Yb

Senator Joe Manchin of West Virginia, who took more campaign cash from the oil and gas industry than any other senator, blew up the Democratic Party’s plan to fight climate change.
Here’s a look at how the plan unraveled as the Earth continues to warm. https://t.co/js6zCTQvg9 https://t.co/DsXbOzG8XY

Images released by NASA this from the James Webb Space Telescope show ancient galaxies and fledgling stars.
What can the spectacular images teach us about the universe? Listen to today’s episode of The Daily. https://t.co/1X6sFt9Eyd

Representative Lauren Boebert’s gun-themed restaurant, where waitresses served “Rifle Toast” and “Shotgun” burritos with guns holstered on their hips, closed on Sunday after the building’s landlord decided not to renew the lease. https://t.co/iZGmIpfEAp

A document obtained by The New York Times shows that the Indiana obstetrician who provided abortion care to a 10-year-old rape victim reported the child’s abortion to the state, contrary to the assertions of Indiana’s attorney general. https://t.co/d9exGs9BSg

Ray Epps was taped before Jan. 6 urging people to go to the Capitol. Then he became the face of a conspiracy theory by pro-Trump forces that the FBI was behind the riot. Since then, he has been forced to sell his home and his business — and go into hiding. https://t.co/2IQEwLJh0O

Ivana Trump, a former wife of Donald Trump, died on Thursday at 73. The police are investigating whether she fell down the stairs at her Manhattan townhouse, according to officials. https://t.co/X7h5rvOtrB

Jim Thorpe, one of the greatest athletes in history and the victim of what many considered a century-old Olympic injustice, has been restored as the sole winner of the decathlon and pentathlon at the 1912 Stockholm Games. https://t.co/qfpxdLFjux https://t.co/ydY6rzBhhz

Senator Joe Manchin of West Virginia, who took more campaign cash from the oil and gas industry than any other senator, blew up the Democratic Party’s plan to fight climate change.
Here’s a look at how the plan unraveled as the Earth continued to warm. https://t.co/NWhgXJvuut

An X-ray of a painting behind another van Gogh artwork has revealed what seems to be a self-portrait of the artist, experts say. It was uncovered by the National Galleries of Scotland in preparation for an upcoming exhibition. https://t.co/ALJhvykVXE https://t.co/YrTJxKCgHI

President Emmanuel Macron of France warned that the country should brace itself for a cutoff of Russian natural gas because of the war in Ukraine. People should prepare to have public lights turned off at night, he said. https://t.co/QKrfUHdM41

Three children were killed by Russian missile strikes on the central Ukrainian city of Vinnytsia on Thursday, President Volodymyr Zelensky’s office said. "What is this," he asked, "if not an open act of terrorism?" https://t.co/84BYOusV6v
Breaking News: Senator Joe Manchin said he wouldn’t support funding for climate programs or raising taxes on the wealthy, a major blow for the Biden agenda. https://t.co/WgMU7KPtn6
An X-ray of a painting behind another van Gogh artwork has revealed what seems to be a self-portrait of the artist, experts say. https://t.co/hR0uyg0AsW

"I heard that you moved from New Jersey to Pennsylvania to look for a new job," Snooki says to Mehmet Oz in a new video shared by his Democratic opponent for the open Senate seat in Pennsylvania, John Fetterman. https://t.co/Rr6hP2TCPo

A document obtained by The New York Times shows that the Indiana obstetrician who provided abortion care to a 10-year-old rape victim reported the child’s abortion to the state, contrary to the assertions of Indiana’s attorney general. https://t.co/nKhmnGTOoN

Just 1% of 18-to-29-year-olds strongly approve of the way President Biden is handling his job, a survey from The New York Times and Siena College found. And 94% of Democrats under 30 said they wanted another candidate to run two years from now. https://t.co/y9xCDeVxSg
Text messages sent and received by Secret Service agents around the time of the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol have been erased, an inspector general said on Thursday. https://t.co/zAkaoODZab

Representative Lauren Boebert’s gun-themed restaurant, where waitresses served “Rifle Toast” and “Shotgun” burritos with guns holstered on their hips, closed on Sunday after the building’s landlord decided not to renew the lease. https://t.co/av7fOh364h
